page.title: The Tale of Auðun of the West Fjords

revision.text:
'''''Auðunar þáttr vestfirska''''' ('''''The Tale of Auðun of the West Fjords''''') is a short tale (or [[þáttr]]) preserved in three distinct versions as part of the saga of [[Harald III of Norway]] (reigned 1047–66, a.k.a. Haraldr inn harðráði Sigurðsson), as the saga is told in the manuscripts [[Morkinskinna]], [[Flateyjarbók]], and several others. Widely translated and anthologised, it is admired for its beautifully simple account<ref>Gwyn Jones, in the introduction to his ''Eirik the Red and Other Icelandic Sagas'', Oxford, 1961, which includes it, calls it "so seeming-simple, . . . the best of all Icelandic ''þættir'' and one of the most flawless short stories ever written" (p. xv).</ref> of a poor Icelander from the [[Westfjords]], the harshest region of the country, who decides to take a polar bear as a present to [[Sweyn II of Denmark]] (reigned 1047-74/76, a.k.a. Sveinn Úlfsson). Auðun sticks to his task despite having to pass through the court of Haraldr, who is continually at odds with Sweyn, and proceeds on a pilgrimage to Rome. Auðun's mixture of determination, audacity and humility leads him to gain the respect of both kings, and through him their respect for one another increases also.
Although ostensibly historical, the work is more plausibly to be seen as 'a historified folktale'.<ref>Marlene Ciklamini, "''Exempla'' in an Old Norse Historiographic Mold", ''Neophilologus'', 81.1 (1997), 71-87, {{doi|10.1023/A:1004216615263}}, at p. 72.</ref>
==Manuscripts==
The tale is preserved in three manuscripts:<ref>{{Cite book|title = Audun and the Polar Bear: Luck, Law, and Largesse in a Medieval Tale of Risky Business|last = Miller|first = William, Ian|publisher = Brill|year = 2014|isbn = 9789004271937|location = Leiden; Boston|pages = 3–4|url = http://www-personal.umich.edu/~wimiller/audunmiller8.pdf|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150608090531/http://www-personal.umich.edu/~wimiller/audunmiller8.pdf|archive-date = 2015-06-08|orig-year = 2008}} (Link to gratis copy, without index, from author's personal webpage.)</ref> * [[Morkinskinna]] (c. 1275) * [[Flateyjarbók]] (c. 1390) * [[Hulda-Hrokkinskinna|Hulda]] (c. 1350-1374<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hulda {{!}} Manuscript {{!}} Handrit.is|url = http://handrit.is/en/manuscript/view/da/AM02-066|website = handrit.is|accessdate = 2015-06-08}}</ref>)
==Synopsis== [[File:Map of Auðun's Travels in Auðun's Tale.png|thumb|Map detailing Auðun's course of travel in Auðun's Tale, beginning and ending in Iceland.]]
Auðun of the Westfjords is a poor man working for his relative Þorstein. A Norwegian ship arrives and Auðun aids the captain Þórir with advice and sells goods for him. In return, Þórir grants Auðun passage, and Auðun makes financial arrangements to support his mother for three years. Auðun then travels to Greenland, where he meets a hunter named Eirik and buys a polar bear from him with the remainder of his money. The hunter warns Auðun about spending his entire fortune on the bear, but Auðun does not heed his warning.
Next Auðun travels to Norway and meets [[Harald III of Norway|King Haraldr]] at a feast. The king asks if Auðun will sell or give him the bear, and Auðun replies that he intends to give it as a gift to [[Sweyn II of Denmark|King Sweyn of Denmark]], with whom King Haraldr happens to be at war. Haraldr chastises Auðun for wanting to give a gift to his enemy, but instead of harming Auðun, grants him passage.
By the time Auðun crosses into Denmark, he has run out of provisions for himself and his bear, and a king's steward named Aki offers him help on the condition that he receives ownership of half the bear in return. Auðun is forced to accept and the two men seek audience with the king. King Sweyn banishes Aki for interfering with Auðun's gift-giving, and invites Auðun to stay with him.
After some time, Auðun asks King Sweyn leave to go on [[pilgrimage]] to Rome. The king gives him money and other pilgrims to accompany him and asks him to return to him when he is done.
Auðun successfully completes his pilgrimage, but becomes ill during his return. He arrives back in Denmark, bald and almost completely unrecognizable. King Sweyn's retainers laugh at him, but the king responds by saying that he has provided for his soul more than they have. He gives Auðun new clothes and offers him to stay as his cupbearer. Auðun replies he cannot stay and must return to Iceland, since the three-year period he set money aside to provide for his mother is nearly up. Upon parting, the king gives him a ship, a bag full of silver, and an arm ring, saying that he should only give the ring to a high-ranking person if he needs to repay a debt.
After departing, Auðun travels back to Norway and relates his experiences with King Sweyn to King Haraldr, from his acceptance of the bear to funding his pilgrimage to Rome and hospitality. Auðun describes his gifts from King Sweyn, and with each item, King Haraldr says he would have done the same for Auðun, except the bag of silver. Auðun then comes to the ring, and gives it to King Haraldr, since he owes him for granting him passage to complete his journey. The king accepts the ring, and gives Auðun a sword and cloak before he departs.
Auðun returns to Iceland and has good fortune for the rest of his life there.
==Themes==
Auðun's Tale is driven largely by Auðun's luck. William Ian Miller explains the etymology of Auðun's name, tracing the elements back to vinr, meaning 'friend' and auð, meaning 'luck, good fortune, fate'.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Audun and the Polar Bear: Luck, Law, and Largesse in a Medieval Tale of Risky Business|last = Miller|first = William, Ian|publisher = Brill|year = 2014|isbn = 9789004271937|location = Leiden; Boston|pages = 71–72|url = http://www-personal.umich.edu/~wimiller/audunmiller8.pdf|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150608090531/http://www-personal.umich.edu/~wimiller/audunmiller8.pdf|archive-date = 2015-06-08|orig-year = 2008}} (Link to gratis copy, without index, from author's personal webpage.)</ref> Miller further connects the root of auð to the vað in vaðmál, the woven cloth used as a type of currency in medieval Iceland, and to the spinning and weaving of fate by the [[Norns]]. Thus, Miller argues, Auðun is inherently lucky and the course of his story "exists in embryo in his name."<ref>Miller 2008:73</ref>
Miller rejects scholars' two main theories of Auðun's motives for his behavior: that he is either a holy fool or acting solely out of self-interest.<ref>Miller 2008:85</ref> According to Miller, Auðun's actions are too carefully thought-out for him to be naive, and interprets the purpose of Aki's character as a demonstration that Auðun is not acting out of pure self-interest.<ref>Miller 2008:85</ref> Instead, Miller suggests that Auðun's actions are driven by a combination of self-interest tempered with sincere, noble intentions.<ref>Miller 2008:85-86</ref>
[[Gift|Gift-giving]] and exchange are central to Auðun's Tale. Members of Old Norse society exchanged gifts with each other as a means for establishing and cementing social bonds. A gift normally carried with it an obligation to give a gift in return.<ref>Miller 2008:30</ref> Auðun's Tale explores the implications of gift exchange between social peers of similar standing, between lower and higher standing (such as Auðun and King Haraldr and King Sweyn), and between humans and God (Auðun going on pilgrimage to Rome). Edward G. Fichtner sees the story representing Auðun's coming of age "by his learning how to participate in the exchange of gifts in his culture"<ref>{{cite journal |last=Fichtner |first=Edward G. |date=Summer 1979 |title=Gift Exchange and Initiation in the "Auðunar þáttr vestfirzka" |journal=Scandinavian Studies |volume=51 |issue=3 |pages=249–272}}</ref>
==Editions and translations== {{wikiquote}}
===Flateyjarbók version===
* ''Flateyjarbók: en samling af norske konge-sagaer med indskudte mindre fortællinger om begivenheder i og udenfor Norge samt annaler'', 3 vols, ed. Guðbrandur Vigfússon and C.R. Unger (Christiania [Oslo], 1860–1868). Audun’s Story at 3:411–415. https://books.google.com/books?id=qWgJAAAAQAAJ& * William Ian Miller, ''Audun and the Polar Bear Luck, Law, and Largesse in a Medieval Tale of Risky Business'', Medieval Law and its Practice, 1 (Leiden: Brill, 2014). Translation into English pp. 7–12. * Hermann Pálsson, ''Hrafnkel’s Saga and other Stories'' (Harmondsworth, 1971). Translation into English pp. 121–128.
===Morkinskinna version===
* ''Morkinskinna: The Earliest Icelandic Chronicle of the Norwegian Kings (1030–1157)'', trans. by Theodore M. Andersson and Kari Ellen Gade, Islandica 51 (Ithaca, NY, 2000). Translation into English pp. 211–215 (M ch. 36). * ''Vestfirðinga sögur'', ed. Björn K. Þórólfsson and Guðni Jónsson, Íslenzk fornrit, 6 (Reykjavík, 1943). Includes Morkinskinna version of ''Auðunar þáttr''. * [http://www.heimskringla.no/wiki/Au%C3%B0unar_%C3%BE%C3%A1ttr_vestfirzka Auðunar þáttr vestfirzka] from heimskringla.no * [http://www.snerpa.is/net/isl/audun.htm Auðunar þáttur vestfirska] from snerpa.is * Arnold R. Taylor, “Auðunn and the Bear,” ''Saga-Book of the Viking Society'' 13 (1946–53), 81–87. * Gwyn Jones, ''Eirik the Red and other Icelandic Sagas'' (Oxford, 1961). Translation into English pp. 163–170. * 'The Story of Audunn and the Bear', trans. by G. Turville-Petre, in ''Seven Icelandic Short Stories'', ed. by Ásgeir Pétursson and Steingrímur J. Þorsteinsson (Reykjavík: Ministry of Education, 1960), at http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/5603. From Morkinskinna 'except in a few cases where reference has been made' to Hulda and Flateyjarbók.
===Hulda version===
* ''Fornmanna Sögur'', ed. Sveinbjörn Egilsson, et al., 12 vols (Copenhagen, 1825–1837). The Hulda ms. version of Audun’s Story, 6:297–307.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Þættir}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Audunar Thattr Vestfirzka}} [[Category:Þættir]] [[Category:Sagas of Icelanders]] [[Category:Medieval literature]] [[Category:Icelandic literature]]

{{About|the Van Gogh paintings|the crop|wheat|other uses|Wheatfield (disambiguation)}} {{about|paintings made in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence|the general series|Wheat Fields (Van Gogh series)}}
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Vincent Willem van Gogh 007.jpg | title=The Wheat Field, Sunrise | artist=[[Vincent van Gogh]] | year=1890 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=72 | width_metric=92 | height_imperial=28.3 | width_imperial=36.2 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Otterlo]] | museum=[[Kröller-Müller Museum]] }}
'''''The Wheat Field''''' is a series of oil paintings executed by [[Vincent van Gogh]] in [[Saint-Rémy-de-Provence]]. All of them depict the view Van Gogh had from the window of his bedroom on the top floor of the asylum: a field enclosed by stone walls just beneath his window and excluded from normal life by the rear wall of the asylum grounds; beyond this enclosure farm land, accompanied by olive groves and vineyards, ran up to the hills at the foot of the mountain range called [[Alpilles|Les Alpilles]].
From May 1889 to May 1890, Van Gogh recorded this view in changing settings: after a storm, with a reaper in the field, with fresh wheat raising in autumn and with flowers in the spring. This is one of Van Gogh's major series from Saint-Rémy, comprising wonderful works such as the ''Wheat Field at Sunrise'' in the Kröller-Müller Museum. Van Gogh included the ''Enclosed Field with Rising Sun'' (F737) made in December 1889 in his [[The Display at Les XX 1890|Display at Les XX 1890]] in Brussels.
Van Gogh worked on a group of paintings "The Wheat Field" that he could see from his cell at Saint-Paul Hospital. From the studio room he could see a field of wheat, enclosed by a wall. Beyond that were the mountains from Arles. During his stay at the asylum he made about twelve paintings of the view of the enclosed wheat field and distant mountains.<ref name="PMA">{{cite web |url=http://www.philamuseum.org/collections/permanent/82820.html?mulR=32251%7c1 |title=Rain |year=2011 |work=Collections |publisher=Philadelphia Museum of Art |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> In May Van Gogh wrote to Theo, "Through the iron-barred window I see a square field of wheat in an enclosure, a perspective like Van Goyen, above which I see the morning sun rising in all its glory."<ref>{{cite book | title=Van Gogh and God: A Creative Spiritual Quest | author=Edwards, C | publisher=Loyola Press | location=Chicago | year=1989 | page=104 | isbn=0-8294-0621-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fYA9QzwvsekC&pg=PA104 }}</ref> The stone wall, like a picture frame, helped to display the changing colors of the wheat field.<ref name="Fell40"/>
==Spring and summer, 1889== The [[Kröller-Müller Museum]]'s ''Enclosed Wheat Field with Rising Sun'' was painted in May 1889.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kmm.nl/object/KM%20106.596/Enclosed-wheat-field-with-rising-sun |title=Enclosed Wheat Field with Rising Sun |year= |work=Collection |publisher=[[Kröller-Müller Museum]] |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> Van Gogh used the rising sun above fields of wheat to represent its life giving energy.<ref name="Fell40">{{cite book | title=Van Gogh's Gardens | author=Fell, D | publisher=Simon & Schuster | location=United Kingdom | year=2001 | page=40 | isbn=0-7432-0233-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QssD77mFRkkC&pg=PA40}}</ref>
''Green Wheat Field'' was painted in June 1889.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/179/Green-Wheat-Field.html |title=Green Wheat Field |year=2011 |work=Saint-Rémy |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> Van Gogh had a tender feeling about green wheat, likening it to that of a baby: "Young wheat has something inexpressibly pure and tender about it, which awakens the same emotion as the expression of a sleeping baby." Towards the end of his life he regarded his most delicate works, a young wheat field with the rising sun or a blooming orchard, as his "babies."<ref name="Lubin">{{cite book | title=Stranger on the Earth: A Psychological Biography of Vincent van Gogh | author=Lubin, A | publisher=De Capo Press | location=United States | year=1996 | origyear=1972 | page=17 | isbn=0-306-80726-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BHVwceHVI5cC&pg=PR17 }}</ref>
Van Gogh describes ''Mountainous Landscape Behind Saint-Rémy,'' also made in June, as a view taken in the hills seen from his bedroom window: "In the foreground, a field of wheat ruined and hurled to the ground by a storm. A boundary wall and beyond the grey foliage of a few olive trees, some huts and the hills. Then at the top of the canvas a great white and grey cloud floating in the azure."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/20/594.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Theo van Gogh, Saint-Rémy, c. 9 June 1889 | editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits (funded in part by U.S. Department of Education, Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education) |accessdate=April 6, 2011}}</ref>
{| |[[Image:Vincent Willem van Gogh 007.jpg|thumb|160px|''Enclosed Wheat Field with Rising Sun,'' May 1889, [[Kröller-Müller Museum]], [[Otterlo]], [[Netherlands]] (F720 ) ]] |[[Image:Van Gogh - Grünes Weizenfeld.jpeg|thumb|160px|''Green Wheat Field,'' June 1889, owner unclear, possibly on loan to Kunsthaus Zurich, Zurich (F718 )]] |[[File:Vincent van Gogh - Landscape from Saint-Rémy - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|160px|''Mountainous Landscape Behind Saint-Rémy,'' June 1889, [[Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek]], [[Copenhagen]] (F611 ) ]] |}
In late June Van Gogh painted ''Wheat Field with Reaper and Sun''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kmm.nl/object/KM%20101.173/Wheat-field-with-reaper-and-sun |title=Wheat Field with Reaper and Sun | year= | work=Collection |publisher=Kröller-Müller Museum | accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> which he described as "a wheat field, very yellow and very light, perhaps the lightest canvas I have done."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/20/596.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Theo van Gogh, Saint-Rémy, 25 June 1889 | editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits (funded in part by U.S. Department of Education, Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education) |accessdate=April 6, 2011}}</ref>
In July he painted Kröller-Müller Museum's ''Landscape with Wheat Sheaves and Rising Moon''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kmm.nl/object/KM%20107.656/Landscape-with-wheat-sheaves-and-rising-moon |title=Landscape with Wheat Sheaves and Rising Moon |year= |work=Collection |publisher=Kröller-Müller Museum |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> which he describes as "a moonrise over the same field as the sketch in Gauguin's letter, but in it some stacks take the place of the wheat. It is dull yellow-ochre and violet."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/20/603.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Theo van Gogh, Saint-Rémy, 6 July 1889 | editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits (funded in part by U.S. Department of Education, Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education) |accessdate=April 6, 2011}}</ref>
{| |[[Image:Wheat field with reaper and sun.jpg|thumb|160px|''Wheat Field with Reaper and Sun,'' Late June 1889, Oil on canvas, [[Kröller-Müller Museum]], [[Otterlo]], [[Netherlands]] (F617) ]] |[[Image:Landscape with wheat sheaves and rising moon.jpg|thumb|160px|''Landscape with Wheat Sheaves and Rising Moon,'' July 1889, [[Kröller-Müller Museum]], [[Otterlo]], [[Netherlands]] (F735 ) ]] |}
''Enclosed Field with Ploughman'' was made in August 1889, which is held in a private collection (F625).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/108/Enclosed-Field-with-Ploughman.html |title=Enclosed Field with Ploughman |year= |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref>
==Two complementary fall paintings==
The ''Wheat Field with a Reaper'' was started in the summer before a bout of illness and completed in September.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/20/604.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Theo van Gogh, Saint-Rémy, 5 or 6 September 1889 | editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits (funded in part by U.S. Department of Education, Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education) |accessdate=April 6, 2011}}</ref> Here Van Gogh depicts a reaper in a sun-drenched wheat field. Referring to a Biblical metaphor, Van Gogh wrote of the meaning of this painting, "In this reaper – a vague figure laboring like the devil in the terrible heat to finish his task – I saw an image of death, in the sense that the wheat being reaped represented mankind... But there is nothing sad in this death, it takes place in broad daylight, under a sun that bathes everything in a fine, golden light."<ref name="VGM WF with Reaper">{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghmuseum.nl/vgm/index.jsp?page=2935&lang=en |title=Wheat Field with Reaper |year= |work=Collection |publisher=Van Gogh Museum |accessdate=April 1, 2011}}</ref>
''Enclosed Field with Peasant'' was painted over several days in October, working just outside the hospital. It accurately reflects the topography of the walled wheat field with the peaks of the Alpilles in the background. Van Gogh's brushwork brings life to this picture of furrowed soil and craggy mountains. At the center, a peasant carries a bundle of straw, a symbol of the cycles of life. Van Gogh described this painting as a pendant to ''The Reaper'', which resides at the [[Van Gogh Museum]] in [[Amsterdam]], both in vivid complementary colors of yellow and blue-violet.<ref name="IMA">{{cite web |url=http://www.imamuseum.org/art/collections/artwork/landscape-saint-r%C3%A9my-enclosed-field-peasant-gogh-vincent-van |title=Landscape at Saint-Rémy (Enclosed Field with Peasant) |year=2010 |work=Collection |publisher= |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> Both he considers harsh studies, but instead of being almost entirely yellow like ''The Reaper'', the "picture is almost entirely violet. Broken violet and neutral tints."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/20/610.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Theo van Gogh, Saint-Rémy, c. 8 October 1889 | editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits (funded in part by U.S. Department of Education, Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education) |accessdate=April 6, 2011}}</ref>
{| |[[File:Vincent van Gogh - Wheatfield with a reaper - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|160px|''Wheat Field with Reaper,'' September 1889, [[Van Gogh Museum]], [[Amsterdam]] (F618)]] |[[Image:WLA ima Landscape at St Remy.jpg|thumb|160px|''Landscape at Saint-Rémy (Enclosed Field with Peasant)'' early October 1889, [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]], [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]] (F641)]] |}
==Fall and winter, 1889==
In September Van Gogh worked on ''Wheat Field behind Saint-Paul Hospital with a Reaper.'' Intending to paint a pure sulfur yellow, he wrote to [[Émile Bernard (painter)|Émile Bernard]] that he had taken up the "devil of a question of yellow". He explained to his brother Theo, "I see in this reaper – an undefined figure, struggling in the intense heat like the devil to finish his work – I see him as an image of death in the sense that the humans are the corn that is being cut down. So it is, if you will, the opposite of the sowing that I tried earlier. But this death is not sad, it takes place in bright light with a sun that covers everything with a light like pure gold."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://collection-online.museum-folkwang.de/eMuseumPlus?service=direct/1/ResultLightboxView/result.t1.collection_lightbox.$TspTitleImageLink.link&sp=10&sp=Scollection&sp=SfieldValue&sp=0&sp=0&sp=3&sp=Slightbox_4x5&sp=0&sp=Sdetail&sp=0&sp=F&sp=T&sp=5 |title=Wheat Field behind Saint-Paul Hospital with a Reaper |year= |work=Collection |publisher=Museum Folkwang |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref>
''Rain'' also called ''Enclosed Wheat Field in the Rain'' is unique to Van Gogh's work in the South. He represented falling rain by diagonal lines of paint. The style is reminiscent of Japanese prints, but the effect is stylistically personal to Van Gogh.<ref name="PMA"/>
In December Van Gogh made ''Wheat Field with a Rising Sun,'' held in a private collection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/109/Enclosed-Field-with-Rising-Sun.html |title=Enclosed Field with a Rising Sun |year= |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref> The work, started in late November, shows a sunrise above a field of young wheat in the complementary colors of yellow-green and purple. Deep furrows run towards the enclosed wall behind which is a row of purple hills. The sun is surrounded by a large yellow halo. Van Gogh sough to "express calmness, great peace." Further, he expresses "without making direct reference to the actual [[Christ's Agony at Gethsemane|Gethsemane]]... and there is no need to portray figures from the [[Sermon on the Mount]] in order to express a comforting and gentle motif."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/20/B21.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Emile Bernard, Saint-Rémy, c. 20 November 1889 | editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits (funded in part by U.S. Department of Education, Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education) |accessdate=April 6, 2011}}</ref> It was one of the six canvases he selected for the exhibit at Les Vingt [XX] in Brussels in 1890.<ref>{{cite book | title=Vincent van Gogh: Between Earth and Heaven: The Landscapes |author1=van Gogh, V |author2=Blotkamp, C |author-link2=Carel Blotkamp |author3=Zimmer, N | year=2009 | page=55 }}</ref>
{| |[[Image:Van Gogh - Weizenfeld hinter dem Hospital Saint-Paul (Die Ernte).jpeg|thumb|160px|''Wheat Field behind Saint-Paul with Reaper'', September 1889, [[Museum Folkwang]], Essen (F619)]] |[[Image:Van Gogh - Weizenfeld im Regen.jpeg|thumb|160px|''Rain'' or ''Enclosed Wheat Field in the Rain,'' November 1889, [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]], [[Philadelphia]] (F650)]] |[[Image:Vincent Willem van Gogh 063.jpg|thumb|160px|''Enclosed Field with Rising Sun'' also ''The Wheat Field,'' December 1889, Private Collection (F737)]] |}
===''Wheat Field with Cypresses''=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = | header_align = center | header_background = | footer = | footer_align = right | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Vincent van Gogh - Wheat Field with Cypresses - Google Art Project.jpg | width1 = 160 | caption1 = ''[[Wheat Field with Cypresses]],'' June–July 1889, Oil on canvas, 73 x 93.4 cm, [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York (F717) | image2 = Vincent Van Gogh 0020.jpg | width2 = 160 | caption2 = ''A Wheat Field, with Cypresses,'' September 1889, [[National Gallery]], [[London]] (F615) }}The ''Wheat Field with Cypresses'' paintings were made when Van Gogh was able to leave the asylum. Van Gogh had a fondness for cypresses and wheat fields of which he wrote: "Only I have no news to tell you, for the days are all the same, I have no ideas, except to think that a field of wheat or a cypress well worth the trouble of looking at closeup."<ref name="Edwards102">{{cite book | title=Van Gogh and God: A Creative Spiritual Quest | author=Edwards, C | publisher=Loyola Press | location=Chicago | year=1989 | page=102 | isbn=0-8294-0621-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fYA9QzwvsekC&pg=PA102 }}</ref>
In early July Van Gogh wrote to his brother Theo of a work he began in June, ''[[Wheat Field with Cypresses]]'': "I have a canvas of cypresses with some ears of wheat, some poppies, a blue sky like a piece of [[Scotch plaid]]; the former painted with a thick impasto . . . and the wheat field in the sun, which represents the extreme heat, very thick too." Van Gogh who regarded this landscape as one of his "best" summer paintings made two additional oil paintings very similar in composition that fall. One of the two is in a private collection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/works_of_art/collection_database/european_paintings/wheat_field_with_cypresses_vincent_van_gogh/objectview.aspx?collID=11&OID=110000977 |title=Wheat Field with Cypresses |year=2000–2011 |work= |publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref>
London's [[National Gallery]] ''A Wheat Field, with Cypresses'' painting was made in September<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/vincent-van-gogh-a-wheatfield-with-cypresses |title=A Wheat Field, with Cypresses |year= |work=Collection, Vincent van Gogh |publisher=National Gallery, London |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref> which author H.W. Janson describes: "the field is like a stormy sea; the trees spring flamelike from the ground; and the hills and clouds heave with the same surge of motion. Every stroke stands out boldly in a long ribbon of strong, unmixed color."<ref name="Janson">{{cite book | title=A Basic History of Art | author=H. W. Janson | publisher=Harry N. Abrams | location=New York | year=1971 | chapter=The Modern World | page=308 | isbn=0-13-389296-4 }}</ref>
There is also another version of ''Wheat Fields with Cypresses'' made in September with a blue-green sky, reportedly held at the [[Tate Gallery]] in London (F743).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/748/Wheat-Field-with-Cypresses.html |title=Wheat Field with Cypresses |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 10, 2011}}</ref>
===Other wheat field paintings=== Van Gogh describes the ripening ''Green Wheat Field with Cypresses'' painted in June: "a field of wheat turning yellow, surrounded by blackberry bushes and green shrubs. At the end of the field there is a little house with a tall somber cypress which stands out against the far-off hills with their violet-like and bluish tones, and against a sky the color of forget-me-nots with pink streaks, whose pure hues form a contrast with the scorched ears, which are already heavy, and have the warm tones of a bread crust."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.webexhibits.org/vangogh/letter/20/W12.htm |title=Letter from Vincent van Gogh to Wilhelmina van Gogh, Saint-Rémy, 16 June 1889 | editor=Harrison, R |year=2011 |work=Van Gogh Letters |publisher=WebExhibits (funded in part by U.S. Department of Education, Fund for the Improvement of Postsecondary Education) |accessdate=April 6, 2011}}</ref>
In October van Gogh made ''Enclosed Wheat Field with Ploughman.''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mfa.org/collections/object/enclosed-field-with-ploughman-35481 |title=Enclosed Wheat Field with Ploughman |year= |work=Collections |publisher=Museum of Fine Arts, Boston |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}</ref>
{| |[[Image:Vincent van Gogh - Green Field - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|160px|''Green Wheat Field with Cypress,'' 1889, Narodni Gallery, [[Prague]] (F719)]] |[[Image:Van Gogh - Acker mit plügenden Bauern und Mühle.jpeg|thumb|160px|''Enclosed Wheat Field with Ploughman,'' October 1889, [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|Museum of Fine Arts]], [[Boston]] (F706)]] |}
''Wheat Fields in a Mountainous Landscape,'' also titled ''Meadow in the Mountains'' was painted in Late November - early December 1889.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kmm.nl/object/KM%20100.443/Wheat-fields-in-a-mountainous-landscape |title=Wheat Fields in a Mountainous Landscape |year= |work=Collection |publisher=Kröller-Müller Museum |accessdate=March 31, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722231544/http://www.kmm.nl/object/KM%20100.443/Wheat-fields-in-a-mountainous-landscape |archivedate=July 22, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
In November, ''Wheat Field Behind Saint-Paul'' was painted by Van Gogh, now owned by Virginia Museum of Fine Arts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vangoghgallery.com/catalog/Painting/740/Wheat-Field-Behind-Saint-Paul-Hospital.html |title=Wheat Field Behind Saint-Paul |year= |work=Van Gogh Paintings |publisher=Van Gogh Gallery |accessdate=April 3, 2011}}</ref>
{| |[[Image:A Meadow in the Mountains Le Mas de Saint-Paul 1889 Vincent van Gogh.jpg|thumb|160px|''Wheat Fields in a Mountainous Landscape,'' Late November-Early December 1889, [[Kröller-Müller Museum]], [[Otterlo]], [[Netherlands]] (F721)]] |[[Image:Van Gogh - Weizenfeld hinter dem Hospital Saint-Paul.jpeg|thumb|160px|''Wheat Field Behind Saint-Paul,'' November 1889, [[Virginia Museum of Fine Arts]], [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]], [[Virginia]] (F722)]] |}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * [http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/upload/pdf/leighton_reeve_roy_white1987.pdf Leighton, J., Reeve, A., Roy, A., White, R. ‘Vincent Van Gogh’s “A Cornfield, with Cypresses”‘]. ''National Gallery Technical Bulletin'' Vol 11, pp 42–59. * [https://www.jstor.org/stable/3045988 Jirat-Wasiutyński, V. Vincent van Gogh’s Paintings of Olive Trees and Cypresses from St.-Rémy]. ''The Art Bulletin'', 75(4), 1993, 647–670 * [http://colourlex.com/project/van-gogh-wheatfield-cypresses/ Vincent Van Gogh, ''Wheatfield with Cypresses''], Colourlex
{{Vincent van Gogh}}

revision.comment: /* Items made by soldiers */ adding pair of images
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{original research|date=January 2008}} {{refimprove|date=January 2008}} }} [[Image:Blighty.jpg|thumb|150px|right|A shell case embossed with an image of two wounded Tommies approaching the White Cliffs of Dover]]
'''Trench art''' is any decorative item made by soldiers, prisoners of war, or civilians where the manufacture is directly linked to armed conflict or its consequences. It offers an insight not only to their feelings and emotions about the war, but also their surroundings and the materials they had available to them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.armymuseum.co.nz/whats-on/world-war-one-centenary/personal-treasures-wwi-trench-art/|title=Personal Treasures: WWI Trench Art|website=New Zealand Army Museum|accessdate=22 April 2015}}</ref>
Not limited to the World Wars, the history of trench art spans conflicts from the [[Napoleonic Wars]] to the present day. Although the practice flourished during World War I, the term 'trench art' is also used to describe souvenirs manufactured by service personnel during World War II. Some items manufactured by soldiers, prisoners of war or civilians during earlier conflicts have been retrospectively described as trench art.
<gallery heights=200px widths=200px perrow="4"> Douilles sculptées.jpg|Pair of shell cases with the names of two French villages totally destroyed and not rebuilt later 8Cm Shell Art.jpg|WWI trench art with etchings of a horse and horse shoes on an 80 mm shell casing. Dump of 18 pounder shell cases.jpg|Expended 18 pound artillery shell casings. </gallery>
== Categorisation == There are four broad categories of trench art:
===Items made by soldiers=== {{multiple image | footer = Two [[chestnut]] leaves, engraved by a French soldier with the names of his children "Andrée" and "Eléonore" while waiting in the trenches. | image1 = "Andrée".jpg | image2 = "Eléonore".jpg }} There is much evidence to prove that some trench art was made in the trenches, by soldiers, during war.
In ''With a Machine Gun to Cambrai'', [[George Coppard]] tells of pressing his uniform buttons into the clay floor of his trench, then pouring molten lead from shrapnel into the impressions to cast replicas of the regimental crest.{{CN|date=April 2017}}
Chalk carvings were also popular, with contemporary postcards showing carvings in the rocky outcrops of [[Dugout (military)|dug-outs]].{{CN|date=April 2017}}
Many smaller items such as rings and knives were made by soldiers either in front line or support trenches, especially in quieter parts of the line.{{CN|date=April 2017}}
Wounded soldiers were encouraged to work at crafts as part of their recuperation, with embroidery and simple forms of woodwork being common. Again from ''With a Machine Gun to Cambrai'', George Coppard recalls that, while recuperating from wounds at a private house in [[Birkenhead]], "one kind old lady brought a supply of coloured silks and canvas and instructed us in the art of [[embroidery]]. A sampler which I produced under her guidance so pleased her that she had it framed for me."
An example of therapeutic embroidery during World War I is the work of British military in Egypt, who were photographed sewing and embroidering for Syrian refugees. There was also the Bradford Khaki Handicrafts Club, which was funded in Bradford, UK, in 1918, to provide occupational therapy and employment for men returning from the trenches in France|url=https://trc-leiden.nl/trc-needles/organisations-and-movements/charities/bradford-khaki-handicrafts-club.
===Items made by POWs and internees=== The second category consists of items made by prisoners of war and interned civilians.
[[Prisoners of war|POWs]] had good reasons to make decorative objects: free time and limited resources. Much POW work was therefore done with the express intention of trading the finished article for food, money or other privileges.
Reference to POW work is made in the recollections of A B Baker, W.A.A.C., contained in the book ''Everyman at War'', published by Purdom in 1930: "Part of my work had to do with prisoners quartered in a camp near to our own. Those Germans were friendly men. They were clever with their hands, and would give me little carvings which they had made."
===Items made by civilians=== [[File:Trench Art.JPG|left|thumb|Chromed metal trench art ashtray made from a 25 pounder shell casing, 1942]] The third category is items made by civilians, which mainly means civilians in and around the conflict zone, but would also include items made by sweethearts at home.
In 1914, the US set up the [[Commission for Relief in Belgium]], headed by [[Herbert Hoover]]. It shipped staple foodstuffs, mainly flour, in the printed cotton flour sacks typical of the period. As thanks, the Belgians would embroider and paint in the designs, elaborating them with dates and flags and send them back to the US. Examples of these are now in the [[Herbert Hoover Presidential Library and Museum|Herbert Hoover Museum]], but some were sold to soldiers in Paris or given as gifts.
Civilians in France, in the zones occupied by troops, were quick to exploit a new market. Embroidered [[postcard]]s were produced in what quickly became a [[cottage industry]], with civilians buying the surrounds and embroidering a panel of gauze. These postcards depicted regimental crests or patriotic flags and national symbols in abundance, and millions were produced over the course of the war.
At war's end, when civilians began to reclaim their shattered communities, a new market appeared in the form of pilgrims and tourists. Over the ensuing twenty years mountains of discarded debris, shell casings, and castoff equipment were slowly recycled, with mass-produced town crest motifs being stuck onto bullets, shell casings, fuse caps, and other [[wikt:paraphernalia|paraphernalia]] to be sold to tourists.
===Commercial items=== The fourth category is purely commercial production. After the war, [[tonne]]s of surplus materials were sold by the government and converted to souvenirs of the conflict.
Ship breaking, particularly if the ship had been involved in significant events such as the [[Battle of Jutland]], resulted in much of the wood from the ship being turned into miniature barrels, letter racks, and boxes, with small brass plaques attached announcing, for example, "Made of [[teak]] from HMS ''Shipsname'', which fought at the Battle of Jutland".
==See also== *[[Visual arts and design]] *[[Outsider art]]
== Further reading== *Kimball, Jane A. ''Trench Art: An Illustrated History.'' Davis, CA: Silverpenny Press, 2004. *[[Nicholas J. Saunders|Saunders, Nicholas J.]] ''Trench Art: Materialities & Memories of War.'' Oxford: Berg Publishers, 2003. *Toller, Jane. ''Prisoners-of-War Work, 1756-1815.'' Cambridge: The Golden Head Press, 1965.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Trench art}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20010302124109/http://www.trenchart.org/ Trench art of World War I] * [http://www.trenchart.co.uk/ The UK Trench Art Site] * [http://www.trenchartofww1.co.uk/ Trench art of WW1] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160302102245/http://www.mayawomba.com/ WW1 Trench Art] * {{fr}} https://web.archive.org/web/20090708124947/http://www.artisanat-de-tranchees.fr/accueil-22.html * {{fr}} http://www.souvenirsdelagrandeguerre.com
[[Category:Military art]] [[Category:Recycling]] [[Category:Trench warfare]]

{{Infobox film | name = Vicky Cristina Barcelona | image = Vicky Cristina Barcelona film poster.png | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Woody Allen]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Letty Aronson]] * Jaume Roures * [[Stephen Tenenbaum]] * [[Gareth Wiley]] }} | writer = Woody Allen | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Javier Bardem]] * [[Penélope Cruz]] * [[Scarlett Johansson]] * [[Patricia Clarkson]] * [[Kevin Dunn]] * [[Rebecca Hall]] * [[Chris Messina]] }}<!--- per poster billing block ---> | narrator = [[Christopher Evan Welch]] | cinematography = [[Javier Aguirresarobe]] | editing = [[Alisa Lepselter]] | studio = {{Plainlist| * [[Mediapro]] * [[Wild Bunch (company)|Wild Bunch]] }} | distributor = {{Plainlist| * Mediapro (Spain) * [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] * [[The Weinstein Company]] (United States) }} | released = {{Film date|2008|05|17|[[2008 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes Film Festival]]|2008|8|15|United States|2008|9|19|Spain}} | runtime = 97 minutes | country = {{Plainlist| * Spain * United States }} | language = {{Plainlist| * English * Spanish }} | budget = $15 million<ref name="budget">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/6922536.stm|title=Allen film funding angers Spanish|publisher=BBC News Online |date=2007-07-30}}</ref> | gross = $96.4 million<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=vickycristinabarcelona.htm |title= Vicky Cristina Barcelona |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date=2009-02-19 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> }}
'''''Vicky Cristina Barcelona''''' is a 2008 [[Romance film|romantic]] [[comedy-drama]] film written and directed by [[Woody Allen]]. The plot centers on two American women, Vicky and Cristina, who spend a summer in [[Barcelona]], where they meet an artist, Juan Antonio, who is attracted to both of them while still enamored of his mentally and emotionally unstable ex-wife María Elena. The film was shot in Spain in Barcelona, [[Avilés]] and [[Oviedo]], and was Allen's fourth consecutive film shot outside the United States.
The film premiered at the [[2008 Cannes Film Festival]], then received a rolling worldwide general release that started on August 15, 2008, in the United States, and continued in various countries until its June 2009 release in Japan. The film was nominated for four [[Golden Globe Award]]s, including nominations for Bardem, Hall and Cruz for Best Actor, Best Actress, and Best Supporting Actress, respectively, and won the award for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy|Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy]]. Cruz won both the [[Academy Award]] and [[BAFTA Award]] for Best Actress in a Supporting Role. Altogether, the film won 25 out of 56 nominations.
==Plot== Vicky and Cristina visit Barcelona for the summer, staying with Vicky's distant relative Judy and her husband Mark. While the two are great friends, Vicky is practical and traditional in her approach to love and commitment and is engaged to the reliable Doug, whereas Cristina imagines herself to be a nonconformist, spontaneous but unsure of what she wants from life or love.
At an art exhibition, Cristina is intrigued by artist Juan Antonio, who Judy says has suffered a violent relationship with his ex-wife. Later, he brazenly approaches the two women to invite them to join him right away for the weekend in the city of [[Oviedo]], in a small plane he flies himself, for sight-seeing, fine eating and drinking, and hopefully, lovemaking. Cristina is won over by the offer almost at once, but Vicky is unimpressed and reluctant; she, however, eventually decides to accompany her friend anyway, mainly to watch over her.
At the end of their first day, Vicky refuses to join Juan Antonio in his hotel room, citing her fidelity to Doug, but Cristina accepts his invitation immediately. Before the lovemaking starts, Cristina suddenly falls ill with digestive complaints, and is put to bed, with food poisoning. Vicky and Juan Antonio proceed to spend the weekend together alone while they wait for Cristina to recuperate. Vicky gradually changes her opinion of Juan Antonio as he tells her about his tumultuous relationship with his former wife, María Elena. Vicky accompanies him to visit his father, an old poet, and then becomes deeply moved by a Spanish guitar performance later that evening. She finally succumbs to Juan Antonio's advances as they walk through a grove of trees in the dark. The next day, with Cristina recovered, the three of them fly back to Barcelona.
Feeling guilty, Vicky does not mention the incident to Cristina, and the two begin to grow apart. Vicky starts throwing herself into her studies while Cristina and Juan Antonio take up a relationship. Cristina then moves in with Juan Antonio and begins to discover more about his past. After learning that María Elena attempted to kill herself, Juan Antonio takes her to his home, where Cristina already lives. After some defiance, the two women grow fond of each other. Cristina realizes that the ex-spouses are still in love, and María Elena suggests that Cristina may be the element that can give balance and stability to their relationship. All three become romantically involved with one another.
In the meantime, Vicky is joined in Spain by an enthusiastic Doug and the two get married. When Cristina describes her new life with Juan Antonio to Vicky, Vicky becomes secretly jealous, and after a few other awkward moments, she realizes she is unsatisfied in her married life and is still attracted to Juan Antonio. Learning that Judy is similarly unhappy in her marriage, she confides to her, and Judy, who sees her younger self in Vicky, decides to bring Juan Antonio and Vicky together. Meanwhile, Cristina becomes restless and at some point decides to leave Juan Antonio and María Elena; without her, their relationship quickly falls apart again.
As the summer winds to a close, Judy arranges for Juan Antonio and Vicky to meet at a party. Juan Antonio begs Vicky to meet him again privately before leaving Spain, which she finally accepts, lying to Doug in the process. At his home, Juan Antonio seduces and wins Vicky over again, but they are interrupted by María Elena who bursts in with a gun, firing wildly as Juan Antonio tries to calm her. Vicky gets shot in the hand in the process, and leaves, shouting they are insane and she could never live like this. She confesses the entire story to Cristina, who never realized how Vicky felt about Juan Antonio, and wishes she could have helped her. Doug, Vicky and Cristina return to the United States; Doug never learns what truly happened, Vicky goes back to her married life, and Cristina is back where she started, still unsure of what she wants from life or love.
==Cast== * [[Javier Bardem]] as Juan Antonio Gonzalo * [[Penélope Cruz]] as María Elena * [[Scarlett Johansson]] as Cristina * [[Rebecca Hall]] as Vicky * [[Patricia Clarkson]] as Judy Nash * [[Kevin Dunn]] as Mark Nash * [[Chris Messina]] as Doug * [[Pablo Schreiber]] as Ben * [[Carrie Preston]] as Sally * [[Zak Orth]] as Adam * [[Julio Perillán]] as Charles * [[Christopher Evan Welch]] as narrator
Spanish actor Joan Pera, who dubbed Allen's voice in his previous films, makes a [[cameo appearance]].<ref>(2007-04-12). [http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/film/article1646152.ece Woody Allen rewards Spanish alter ego with role in new film]. ''[[The Times]]''. Retrieved 2010-11-27.</ref>
==Production== In 2007, controversy arose in [[Catalonia]] (Spain) because the film was partially funded with public money; Barcelona's city hall provided one million [[euro]] and the [[Generalitat de Catalunya]] (Government of Catalonia) half a million, or ten percent of the film's budget.<ref name="budget"/>
This was the third time Johansson and Allen worked together, following ''[[Match Point]]'' (2005) and ''[[Scoop (2006 film)|Scoop]]'' (2006). This also marked the second time Johansson and Hall worked together, the first time being in ''[[The Prestige (film)|The Prestige]]'' (2006).
The film featured several paintings by Catalan artist Agustí Puig.
==Critical reception==
===Box office=== {{As of|2009|July}}, the film grossed $96 million worldwide; in relation to its $15 million budget,<ref name="budget"/> it is one of Allen's most profitable films.<ref>{{mojo title|id=vickycristinabarcelona}}</ref>
===Reviews=== ''Vicky Cristina Barcelona'' garnered the best reviews Allen received since his [[Academy Award]]-nominated 2005 film ''[[Match Point]]'' (also starring Johansson), particularly for Cruz's performance, earning a rating of 81% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]].<ref name="rtvicky">{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/vicky_cristina_barcelona/ |title=Vick Cristina Barcelona |accessdate=2009-07-06|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]}}</ref>
Scott Tobias wrote in ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' that it was "a witty and ambiguous movie that's simultaneously intoxicating and suffused with sadness and doubt".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/content/cinema/vicky_cristina_barcelona|title=Vicky Cristina Barcelona|publisher=Onion AV Club|accessdate=August 15, 2008}}</ref> [[Richard Roeper]] suggested that Cruz should receive an [[Academy Award]] nomination for her role.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bventertainment.go.com/tv/buenavista/ebertandroeper/index2.html?sec=1&subsec=5843|archive-url=https://archive.is/20080828024322/http://bventertainment.go.com/tv/buenavista/ebertandroeper/index2.html?sec=1&subsec=5843|dead-url=yes|archive-date=August 28, 2008|title=Ebert & Roeper - Vicky Cristina Barcelona|publisher=Buena Vista TV|accessdate=August 15, 2008}}</ref> [[Mick LaSalle]] of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' praised the film as "the work of a confident and mature artist", referring to Allen.<ref name="LaSalleSFChronicle">{{cite web |url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/08/15/DD62124RD6.DTL |title= Movie review: 'Vicky Cristina Barcelona' |author= Mick LaSalle | authorlink = Mick LaSalle |work= [[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date= August 15, 2008 }}</ref> [[Manohla Dargis]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote "Although ''Vicky Cristina'' trips along winningly, carried by the beauty of its locations and stars — and all the gauzy romanticism those enchanted places and people imply — it reverberates with implacable melancholy, a sense of loss."<ref>[https://movies.nytimes.com/2008/08/15/movies/15barc.html The Portrait of Two Ladies], a review from ''[[The New York Times]]'' August 15, 2008</ref> [[Richard Corliss]] ended his review of the film with "The movie has neither the sardonic heft of [[Max Ophüls]]'s ''[[La Ronde (1950 film)|La Ronde]]'' nor the emotional precision of [[Ingmar Bergman]]'s ''[[Smiles of a Summer Night]]'', two films that also dance the change-partners [[gavotte]]. But ''Vicky Cristina Barcelona'' is so engaging so much of the time that it feels like a modest rejuvenation: evidence that a summer in Spain can do wonders for a writer-director who may not have outlived his prime."<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1833089,00.html Woody Allen's Barcelona Summer of Love]. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. August 15, 2008.</ref> S. Williams of ''Momzone'' magazine singled out Johansson's performance for praise, writing, "Johansson's acting is syrup: fluid and sweet."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pocketfives.com/f13/2014-going-best-year-movie-history-687711/index7.html |title= Is 2014 Going to be the Best Year in Movie History }}</ref> Ian Freer of ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' gave the film 4 out of 5, and wrote "within Allen's recent output, Vicky Cristina is a highlight. See it for beautiful locales, an ambivalent look at human relationships and a clutch of great performances, especially from Cruz."<ref>[http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=136045 Vicky Cristina Barcelona] by Ian Freer of ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]''</ref>
===Top ten lists=== {{Globalize/US|date=June 2011}} The film appeared on many critics' top-ten lists of the best films of 2008.<ref name=mctop08>{{cite web |url=http://apps.metacritic.com/film/awards/2008/toptens.shtml |title=Film Critic Top Ten Lists: 2008 Critics' Picks |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=January 11, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60eITgMHN?url=http://apps.metacritic.com/film/awards/2008/toptens.shtml |archivedate=August 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
{{div col}} * 5th – [[David Denby (film critic)|David Denby]], ''[[The New Yorker]]''<ref name=mctop08/> * 5th – Ray Bennett, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''<ref name=mctop08/> * 5th – Robert Mondello, [[NPR]]<ref name=mctop08/> * 7th – [[Joe Morgenstern]], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''<ref name=mctop08/> * 7th – Keith Phipps, ''[[The A.V. Club]]''<ref name=mctop08/> * 7th – [[Kyle Smith]], ''[[New York Post]]''<ref name=mctop08/> * 7th – Steve Rea, ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]''<ref name=mctop08/> * 8th – [[Mick LaSalle]], ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''<ref name=mctop08/> * 9th – Carrie Rickey, ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]''<ref name=mctop08/> * 10th – [[Michael Sragow]], ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]''<ref name=mctop08/> {{div col end}}
==Awards and nominations== {{unreferenced section|date=October 2011}} The film won the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy]].<ref>{{cite web|title=List of Golden Globe Nominees and Winners|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/08/movies/awardsseason/globenoms08.html?_r=0|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=April 27, 2014}}</ref> Woody Allen won his first [[Independent Spirit Award for Best Screenplay]] and was nominated for the [[Writers Guild of America Award for Best Original Screenplay]].
Penélope Cruz won the Best Supporting Actress award from numerous organizations including: the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]], the [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts]], the [[Independent Spirit Awards]], the [[Boston Society of Film Critics]], the [[Goya Awards]], the Kansas City Film Critics Circle, the [[Los Angeles Film Critics Association]], the [[National Board of Review]], the [[New York Film Critics Circle]], and the Southeastern Film Critics Association.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vicky Cristina Barcelona (2008)|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/389937/Vicky-Cristina-Barcelona/details|accessdate=April 27, 2014|newspaper=New York Times}}</ref>
